repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Development Support Credit
            Series (I-IV) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First and Third
            Development Support Credit (DSC) Project for Bangladesh were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Second Development Support
            Credit Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Fourth Development Support Credit Project were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the Bank must
            maintain a close dialogue with political parties out of
            power and with other key opinion makers to have a better
            assessment of the support for reforms. This approach is
            strategic and must be done even while working closely with
            and supporting like minded governments. Such an approach
            helps to mitigate risks of possible reversals if and when
            the ruling parties change, and to avoid the appearance of
            playing favorites. The Bank needs to do much more targeted
            and tailored engagement and communication with stakeholders,
            quite apart from the Government. This is needed for
            deepening ownership and support for reforms under
            programmatic loans, such as the DSC. Such an approach
            becomes all the more critical during the tenure of an
            elected government which tends to be disproportionately
            sensitive to public opinion and is, oftentimes, reluctant to
            make unpopular policy choices.

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that a
            Development Support Credit (DSC) type operation is not the
            best vehicle to achieve long-term structural change, but it
            can be a good catalyst to initiate it. Likewise, a DSC can
            serve a the final push to implement other reforms that have
            been on the agenda for a long time. The triggers for the
            follow-on DSC 2 were relevant to deepening the program, but
            later needed significant revisions to reflect evolving
            conditions. There was little overlap between the programs of
            the two institutions. The Bank might have had a stronger
            hand in some areas, such as energy pricing, if the IMF had
            had cross conditionality. In the case of time bound
            conditions such as the awarding of the financial advisory
            contract for Nationalized Commercial Banks (NCBs), the
            contractor may take opportunities to increase fees. The
            current Bank timeframe for Bangladesh for public sector bank
            restructuring is about 4 years, whereas in Pakistan, as a
            comparison, it took almost 10 years for a similar financial
            restructuring to take place.

5087060.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Development Support Credit for
            Bangladesh supports the implementation of the
            Government's poverty reduction strategy (PRSP), which
            focuses on: 1) Acceleration of pro-poor growth: The I-PRSP
            aims to raise the economy's growth rate from about 5
            percent per annum to 6-7 percent, in order to attain the
            poverty reduction target in the Millennium Development Goals
            set for 2015. This will be accomplished by (a) ensuring a
            stable macroeconomic environment; (b) relying on the private
            sector as the engine of growth; (c) establishing a sound and
            well-functioning financial system and ensuring that the poor
            have access to financial resources; (d) taking advantage of
            the opportunities provided by globalization, (e) developing
            rural areas and accelerating rural non-farm growth; (f)
            creating the conditions needed for an expanding and dynamic
            manufacturing sector; and (g) substantially augmenting the
            capacity and quality of infrastructure services. 2)
            Promoting Good Governance: The Government's strategy of
            improving governance focuses on addressing three major
            areas: (a) improving the investment climate by creating a
            competitive environment across all segments in society; (b)
            establishing and enforcing clear rules and regulations for
            public sector administration; and (c) promoting voice and
            participation of the civil society, including women, the
            poor and disadvantaged groups, as a step toward a
            transparent and 'open' government. 3) Investing in
            Human Development: This is to be done through targeted
            public expenditures in health, education, and nutrition, and
            radically improved system of incentives for public service
            providers. Within the health sector, although some success
            has been achieved in preventive health care, a small
            proportion of poor people have access to public health care
            services. The strategy thus gives priority to completing the
            unfinished agenda and addressing the pro-poor concerns in
            health and nutrition. The introduction of a national
            nutrition program to address the malnutrition of children
            under two as well as pregnant and lactating mothers through
            the provision of food supplements, nutrition and health
            counseling is a positive step to address the problem. In the
            area of basic education, the plan is to improve quality,
            while increasing access for the poorest segments o f
            society. NGOs and private sector are envisaged as providers
            of high-quality education along with the government. 4)
            Promoting Women's advancement: While the gender-gap is
            closing in Bangladesh for most social indicators, the
            overall level of empowerment measured in terms of literacy,
            work force participation, property rights, and credit
            access, remains low. The strategy for furthering
            women's advancement includes emphasis on policies and
            institutional actions to combat continuing negative gender
            ratios, violence against women, high maternal mortality, and
            restrictions on women's employment and economic
            opportunities; and policies to ensure formal equality;
            supporting affirmative actions at all levels and in all
            spheres; and creating a women-friendly institutional
            environment overall. 5) Ensuring Social Protection: To help
            increase the poor's crisis-coping capability and form
            important risk-insurance policies for them, four sets of
            policies would be emphasized for the poor to cope better
            with various income (consumption) shocks. The first set of
            policies will continue focus on social safety nets; the
            second on policies that will address the vulnerabilities of
            the 'new poor'; the third will emphasize the
            development of social solidarity; and the fourth set
            concerns risk insurance, including measures to mitigate
            risks faced by the poor.
